Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of correct legal test for best interests of the child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly assessed due to procedural errors
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical records, social service reports, internet research (not disclosed)
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4(2) of IRPA regarding best interests of the child
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children without hardship threshold
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied hardship threshold in best interests assessment
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child standard
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Inadequacies in medical care, risk of homelessness, dependency on social services in St. Lucia
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correct legal test under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: Children's vulnerability and integration in Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of correct legal test for best interests of the child and procedural fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to lack of candor
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical records, undisclosed internet evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 4(2) of IRPA regarding best interests of the child
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children and procedural fairness
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied hardship threshold and used undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Best interests of the child standard
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Unique consequences of removal including medical and social risks
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and correct legal test
Crimes.Application_Factor: Reliance on non-disclosed evidence affecting fairness
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in identity or supporting documents

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to leave Canada upon expiration of authorized stay
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tisson remained in Canada beyond her visa validity
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of undisclosed evidence by decision maker
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure of relied-upon evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Partially undermined due to unauthorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child without hardship threshold
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Improper focus on hardship rather than best interests

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of best interests of children in H&C application
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Found lacking due to perceived deceitful behavior
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical records, social support documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Best interests of children in St. Lucia
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Holistic best interests assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Inadequate healthcare, homelessness risk, social service gaps
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Correct interpretation of s. 25(1)
Crimes.Application_Factor: Integration of children in Canada

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Legality of work without proper permit
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer failed to consider full context of removal impact
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Undermined by unauthorized work and stay
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Best interests of child must be primary consideration
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Error in assessment led to unreasonable outcome
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s. 25(1) and administrative law principles
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Emphasis on compliance and rule of law
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Medical reports, school records, housing status

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 84 of IRPA (duty to leave Canada)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Tisson remained in Canada after issuance of removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use of undisclosed evidence in original decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court authority to review immigration decisions
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Impacted by history of non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child standard
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Flawed analysis focusing on hardship instead of best interests
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency and IRCC

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 25(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Family sought to remain in Canada due to daughter Rhea's pediatric cancer treatment
Evidence of medical needs and challenges accessing adequate care in India was presented
Claimant_Status: Applicants for permanent residence on H&C grounds
Residency_Compliance: Compliant with immigration status prior to application
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly consider best interests of the child (BIOC)
Misinterpretation of data on Indian pediatric oncology services
Dismissal of crucial medical and family establishment evidence
Evidence_Used: Documentation of treatment received in Canada
Evidence of family ties and integration in Canada
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to adequately assess submitted medical evidence
Lack of meaningful engagement with BIOC considerations
Decision_Outcome: Refusal of H&C application by immigration officer
Relief_Sought: Remain in Canada on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Decision_Rationale: The decision was unreasonable due to failure to properly analyze key factors including BIOC and quality of medical care abroad
Insufficient justification for dismissing evidence on India's pediatric oncology capacity

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to declare dependent under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer's rejection of the applicant's humanitarian and compassionate grounds application was reasonable
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Outcome: Judicial review granted, matter remitted for reconsideration by a different officer
Evidence_Type: Evidence of educational opportunities, establishment in Canada, hardship in home country
Basis_of_Claim: Applicant not declared as dependent in 1995, leading to exclusion from family sponsorship
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Misapprehension of evidence regarding education and establishment
Application_Error: Failure to declare dependent at time of immigration
Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applies to officer's discretion
Evidence_Ignored: Applicant’s educational goals, tuition constraints, limited time to establish due to visa restrictions
Application_Factor: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds, best interests of the child, establishment in Canada
Document_Fraud: False omission in initial immigration application

Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Application_Facts: Applicant applied for inland exemption on H&C grounds; rejected due to insufficient hardship and establishment evidence
Residency_Compliance: Applicant visited Canada but lacked permanent status
Procedural_Issue: Failure to consider all H&C factors globally
Evidence_Used: Applicant's education plans, ties to Canada, conditions in St. Vincent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient justification for conclusions on establishment and hardship
Decision_Rationale: Misapprehension of evidence on education, underestimation of hardship abroad, inadequate reasoning on establishment

Dispute_Type: Administrative law dispute over immigration decision
Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of immigration officer's decision on H&C grounds
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Court found misapprehension of evidence on education and establishment
Legal_Rule: H&C decisions reviewed on reasonableness standard; factors must be considered globally
Grounds_for_Claim: Errors in assessing education, establishment, and best interests of the child
Outcome_on_Merits: Decision set aside, remitted for reconsideration
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's educational aspirations, lack of integration time due to visa limits
Legal_Framework: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of education, personal circumstances, country conditions
Legal_Provision: Section of IRPA related to H&C considerations

Dispute_Type: Interpretation of humanitarian and compassionate grounds in inland exemption
Legal_Issue: Correct legal test for assessing H&C grounds
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Officer misinterpreted evidence on education and establishment
Legal_Rule: H&C factors must be assessed globally, best interests of child considered without rigid formulas
Grounds_for_Claim: Misapprehension of evidence, inadequate reasons for decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: University acceptance, tuition costs, duration of stay in Canada
Legal_Framework: Procedural fairness and reasonableness in immigration decisions
Evidence_Type: Academic records, financial constraints, personal declarations
Outcome: Case remitted for reconsideration by different officer
Legal_Provision: IRPR provisions on inland exemptions and H&C considerations

Crimes.Crime_Name: Criminal Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Adewole's H&C application was refused due to criminal inadmissibility and lack of updated information.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred by relying on extrinsic evidence unknown to the applicant.
Crimes.Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of refusal of H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness requires disclosing evidence necessary for meaningful participation
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Applicant was aware or had access to the evidence; lawyer received request for updates but did not respond; consent to communication with Institut existed

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the immigration officer erred in relying on extrinsic evidence of which the applicant was unaware
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on Institut Philippe-Pinel letter and CTV report
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant failed to update file despite opportunity
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires reasonable opportunity to participate meaningfully; evidence must be disclosed if it affects response ability
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness due to use of undisclosed evidence
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Failed to respond to request for updated information

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient to support reliance by immigration officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant was aware of reports and had duty to disclose relevant information

Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in law by applying an incorrect test to assess the best interests of the children
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)
Decision_Outcome: Officer's decision found unreasonable; application remitted for reconsideration
Legal_Rule: Officers must consider the best interests of children without requiring 'unusual or disproportionate hardship'
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper assessment of children's best interests in H&C application
Legal_Framework: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds under IRPA
Remedy_Requested: Redetermination of H&C application by a different officer
Outcome: Application dismissed initially; judicial review allowed; case remitted
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 25(1)

Legal_Issue: Best interests of children in H&C assessment
Evidence_Assessment: Harm to children, potential separation, father's presence
Grounds_for_Claim: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds, best interests of children
Key_Evidence_Considered: Impact of separation on children, benefits of parental presence
Legal_Framework: Baker v. Canada, Suresh v. Canada
Defendant_Response: Visa Officer denied application based on risk of separation
Outcome: Case remitted to a different visa officer

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer violated procedural fairness by considering undisclosed allegations of unauthorized work
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Mr. Ronner was aware of past issues regarding unauthorized work
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Foreign nationals must leave Canada by the end of their authorized stay and cannot work without authorization
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged unauthorized work in 1990 and 1992
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Awareness of prior unauthorized work and risk of non-compliance
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard for factual conclusions, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires applicants to know and respond to adverse information
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of compliance vs. past violations
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Extension denied due to unauthorized work history

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of work permit and visitor record extensions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer violated procedural fairness or made unreasonable findings
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' intent to comply questioned due to past behavior
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Compliance with immigration laws and conditions of stay
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Concerns about intent to leave Canada after authorized stay
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Pattern of non-compliance and likelihood of overstaying
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and reasonableness under administrative law
Crimes.Application_Factor: History of compliance versus repeated violations
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Extensions refused based on credibility and compliance concerns
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation through omission or false statements

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to depart Canada by the end of authorized stay
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – obligation to leave at end of authorized period
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Ronner had history of overstays; Ms. Ronner remained beyond validity of visitor record
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to extended stays without authorization
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Implied through continued presence without status
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of intent to leave Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Doubt cast on stated intention to depart after authorized stay
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Extension denied due to risk of further overstaying
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Order quashing refusal and directing reconsideration
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Prior pattern of overstaying and lack of enforceability assurance
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration Officer, reviewed by Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of temporary resident status extensions
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer acted fairly and reasonably in concluding unauthorized work occurred
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants failed to demonstrate future compliance despite past violations
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Prohibition on working without a valid work permit
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Engagement in employment without proper authorization over multiple periods
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Pattern of unauthorized work and lack of credible evidence of future compliance
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard except for procedural fairness (correctness)
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness and reasonableness of decision-making
Crimes.Application_Factor: Duration and repetition of unauthorized work
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Denial upheld due to breach of conditions and non-compliance risk
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not directly alleged, but implications from inconsistent reporting

Legal_Provision_Violated: Statutory limits on visa officer decision-making authority
Governing_Law: Immigration Act, applicable statutory framework governing visa officers' powers
Application_Facts: Visa officer initially refused application on January 10, 1994; issued a new refusal letter on March 16, 1994, with new grounds after applicant's challenge
Misrepresentation_Element: Alleged misrepresentation of qualifications and experience in the initial application
Procedural_Issue: Issuance of a second refusal decision without statutory authority to reconsider
Jurisdictional_Issue: Visa officer lacked jurisdiction to reconsider and issue a new refusal decision after the initial refusal
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of statutory basis for reinitiating decision-making process
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly addressed; focus was on procedural legality
Outcome: Judicial review application dismissed; applicant may seek extension to challenge original January 10, 1994, decision
Relief_Sought: Invalidation of the March 16, 1994, refusal decision
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the visa officer's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of visa officer's decision-making powers
Standard_of_Review: Correctness, as it involves a question of jurisdiction and statutory authority
Decision_Rationale: Once a visa officer exercises statutory authority to refuse an application, they cannot issue a new refusal unless statute permits reconsideration. The officer had no such authority here.

Legal_Issue: Violation of right to fair test under natural justice principles
Evidence_Type: Technical malfunction during English test, unreliable speakers
Legal_Provision: Right to a fair opportunity to demonstrate qualifications
Basis_of_Claim: Faulty equipment compromised fairness of English proficiency test
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Technical issues affecting communication during test
Application_Error: Use of faulty speakers during test
Legal_Standard: Natural justice – fair opportunity to demonstrate qualifications
Decision_Outcome: Retrial ordered with different visa officer

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed persecution in Turkey due to Kurdish ethnicity, Alevi religion, and political activities
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies and delays in the applicant's account
Evidence_Used: Documentary evidence showing general police actions
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies and delays undermining credibility
Relief_Sought: Recognition as a refugee in Canada
Remedy_Sought: Federal Court review of RPD decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under IRPA
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for legal obligations
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error; RPD decision reasonable based on credibility and lack of evidence of targeted persecution

Crime_Name: Judicial Review of Public Service Appeal Board Decision
Legal_Issue: Whether the second selection process was a new process or a corrective measure; whether the Commission had authority to conduct a new selection process
Governing_Law: Public Service Employment Act (PSEA), subsections 21(2), 21(3), and section 10
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review following dismissal of appeal by the Public Service Appeal Board
Evidence_Assessment: Commission's letter stating the nature of the new competition
Decision_Outcome: Appeal Board's decision upheld; judicial review application dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate error by the Appeal Board
Legal_Rule: PSEA allows but does not require corrective measures under subsection 21(3); subsection 21(2) mandates revocation of appointments on successful appeal; merit-based selection under section 10
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Appeal Board in characterizing the second selection process as entirely new rather than a corrective measure
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commission's letter directing a new competition with updated qualifications
Defendant_Response: Commission acted within its authority under PSEA to direct a new selection process
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Appeal Board decision

Application_Facts: Applicant's age, education, ethnic origin, and baptism evidence were not considered; inappropriate questions about religious practices without specialized knowledge
Procedural_Issue: Failure to reasonably consider all evidence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to account for subjective and objective factors
Lack of comprehensive context in credibility analysis
Credibility_Assessment: Assessment found unreasonable due to lack of comprehensive analysis
Decision_Outcome: Refugee status denied by Refugee Protection Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's decision
Decision_Rationale: Decision failed to consider all relevant factors and context; credibility assessment was inadequate

Dispute_Type: Dispute over whether the elimination of a job position constituted a 'discontinuance of function' under the Canada Labour Code
Legal_Issue: Did the Adjudicator correctly determine that there was no discontinuance of function under Section 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code?
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review application in Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: The Applicant failed to provide sufficient evidence to support their claim
Decision_Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Adjudicator's decision upheld
Burden_of_Proof: Applicant had the burden to prove lack of economic justification and improper notification
Legal_Rule: Section 242(3.1)(a) bars complaints if dismissal is due to lack of work or discontinuance of a function, unless economic justification is proven
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unjust dismissal due to elimination of position without economic justification or proper notice
Outcome_on_Merits: Adjudicator's decision found reasonable; complaint not barred by jurisdictional provisions
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of economic justification, notification of termination
Legal_Framework: Canada Labour Code, Part III – Unjust Dismissal
Defendant_Response: Respondent claimed discontinuance of function; Adjudicator found no economic justification
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Adjudicator’s jurisdictional ruling
Outcome: Application dismissed; costs awarded against the Applicant
Legal_Provision: Section 242(3.1)(a) of the Canada Labour Code

Legal_Provision_Violated: section 7 of the Veterans Review and Appeal Board Regulations, SOR/87-601
Governing_Law: Veterans Review and Appeal Board Regulations, SOR/87-601
Application_Facts: Mr. Ladouceur appealed the denial of an increase in his disability pension for post-traumatic arthritis; the Board did not address key medical evidence such as joint pain and stiffness.
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide sufficient reasons for decision; violation of procedural fairness
Evidence_Used: Medical evidence of joint pain and stiffness
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to address key medical evidence
Outcome: Board's decision overturned on judicial review
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasoned justification requirement under administrative law
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient reasons provided by the Board; failure to explain dismissal of appeal and address material evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Adequacy of reasons for finding misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer did not provide sufficient analysis of credibility
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment history documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation in employment details on PR application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of specific inconsistencies identified by Officer
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose or falsify material facts
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence provided by applicant in response to procedural fairness letter
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Material misrepresentation inducing administrative error
Crimes.Application_Factor: Second PR application

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Sufficiency of reasons for inadmissibility finding
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No clear assessment of applicant's credibility provided
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment history records and application materials
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged false statements regarding employment history
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to specify nature and extent of misrepresentation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Procedural fairness and reasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation of material fact that could lead to error
Crimes.Application_Factor: Second PR application
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside, remanded to new Officer

Violation_Type: Failure to provide adequate state protection
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 96, 97
Application_Facts: Ms. Myle experienced domestic violence in St. Vincent and fears persecution due to lack of effective state protection
Procedural_Issue: RPD dismissed claim twice without adequately addressing updated country evidence or credibility of testimony
Evidence_Used: Information on shelters and police response in St. Vincent
Evidentiary_Deficiency: RPD relied on outdated or incomplete country information
Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Myle's testimony found credible by reviewing court
RPD's negative credibility finding deemed unreasonable
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of refugee claim by a new RPD panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Risk of harm due to failure of state protection
Decision_Rationale: RPD failed to consider current evidence on domestic violence and state protection in St. Vincent
Shelter operations and police effectiveness were not properly assessed

Violation_Type: Lack of credible claim for refugee status
Inadequate claim of state protection failure
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution in Slovakia based on Roma ethnicity; inconsistencies in narrative, testimony, and documents; incidents of discrimination did not amount to persecution; inconsistent efforts to seek state protection
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues due to inconsistencies in narrative and documentation
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Board's decision on credibility, persecution, and state protection
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, documentary evidence, record of proceedings before the Board
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in applicant's statements and documents
Credibility_Assessment: Board found applicant's narrative and testimony inconsistent; credibility negatively assessed
Relief_Sought: Overturning of Board's decision on refugee claim
Remedy_Sought: Judicial review of the Board's determination
Decision_Rationale: The Board's findings on credibility, lack of persecution, and adequacy of state protection were reasonable based on the evidence and analysis

Application_Facts: Two sisters applied to visit their brother in Canada; applications refused based on perceived weak ties to Iran
Residency_Compliance: Applicants claimed strong family ties in Iran; officer incorrectly assessed ties as limited
Procedural_Issue: Visa officer failed to meaningfully analyze listed factors
Consideration of irrelevant facts (e.g., mismatched bank turnovers)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of explanation for credibility or reliability assessments
Credibility_Assessment: No explicit finding, but implicit negative assessment due to 'mismatched' bank turnovers
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa refusal decisions
Remedy_Sought: Redetermination of applications by a new visa officer
Decision_Rationale: Decisions lacked sufficient reasoning, failed to properly consider relevant factors, and included irrelevant considerations
Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer at Canadian visa office

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Mr. Yahie's past role in the Somali government
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 35(1)(b); Regulation 16(d)
Decision_Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision remitted for reconsideration
Credibility: Officer did not adequately assess credibility or role influence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to being a prescribed senior official in the service of a government engaging in human rights violations
Violation_Type: Being a senior official in a government engaged in human rights violations
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 35(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Regulation 16(d)
Application_Facts: Mr. Yahie was Director of Human Resources in Somalia's Ministry of Planning, managed 10-15 staff, worked on social projects, reported to higher officials
Residency_Compliance: Application denied based on inadmissibility grounds
Procedural_Issue: Lack of transparency and inadequate reasoning by the Officer
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to analyze level of influence or hierarchy
Credibility_Assessment: Insufficient assessment of whether role met 'senior official' criteria
Decision_Outcome: Original decision set aside; remanded for reconsideration by another officer
Outcome: Denial of permanent residence overturned on judicial review
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a different immigration officer
Legal_Standard_Applied: Definition of 'senior official' under s. 35(1)(b) and Regulation 16(d)
Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to provide sufficient analysis linking Mr. Yahie’s role to significant influence or benefit

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant misrepresented material facts in her permanent residence application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations not credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Contradictory statements in temporary vs. permanent residence applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Discrepancies in profession (lawyer vs. business manager) between applications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of misrepresentation and potential to induce administrative error
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation that could induce error in administration of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Profession and employment history
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible for two years due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False information in immigration application documents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Withholding material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant withheld or misrepresented material facts in her permanent residence application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's explanations not credible
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Discrepancies in profession and legal training between applications
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Failure to disclose consistent professional background and legal training
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of withheld information and risk of administrative error
Crimes.Application_Error: Omission and inconsistency regarding profession and legal qualifications
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Applicant's claim of forgetfulness or agency error
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Withholding material facts that could induce error in administration of IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Professional background and legal education
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Inadmissible for two years due to withholding material facts
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Incomplete or false information in immigration forms

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section related to valid visa duration under immigration law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants remained in the country beyond the authorized period of stay and were subject to a removal order
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review rendered academic due to stay order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Visa records, removal order documentation, court stay order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal and judicial review
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and reconsideration of deferral request
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, depending on issue type
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Stay order halted removal, making the original judicial review application academic

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Enforcement provisions under IRPA regarding removal orders
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants challenged the denial of deferral of removal after a stay was granted by the court
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review rendered academic due to stay order
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration enforcement decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Removal order, deferral request, judicial stay order
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of enforcement decision and deferral of removal
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal and reversal of deferral denial
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Stay of removal eliminated live controversy, rendering the matter moot
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Canada Border Services Agency, Federal Court

Application_Facts: Applicant challenged rejection of PRRA and H&C applications
No new evidence presented in PRRA to overcome credibility issues
Positive H&C factors noted but dismissed without analysis
Country conditions alone deemed insufficient for risk claims
Misrepresentation_Element: Credibility issues in prior application carried forward
Procedural_Issue: Failure to provide adequate reasons for H&C rejection
Lack of oral hearing discretion exercised without explanation
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No new evidence in PRRA to rebut prior adverse credibility finding
Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility assessment maintained due to lack of new evidence
Outcome: H&C decision set aside and remitted
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of PRRA and H&C rejections
Decision_Rationale: PRRA: No new evidence to overcome credibility concerns
H&C: Positive factors acknowledged but inadequately analyzed, reasons insufficient

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility and removal order appeal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD unreasonably assessed the seriousness of misrepresentation and failed to consider a stay under IRPA
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; IAD decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Ms. Li conceded to the fraudulent marriage; lack of remorse noted
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Concession of fraudulent marriage, community involvement, personal hardship claims
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations to avoid removal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Deliberate and serious misrepresentation outweighed positive H&C factors
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Appeal before the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD), followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: No procedural error found; no explicit request for stay made
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of IAD's assessment of misrepresentation and H&C factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None found; IAD considered relevant factors but gave greater weight to fraud
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness applied in judicial review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature of misrepresentation, intent, duration, and impact on immigration system
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Removal order upheld; no stay granted
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Marriage certificate used to falsely establish spousal relationship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Appeal of removal order based on misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD failed to consider a stay of removal and reasonably assessed the seriousness of misrepresentation
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed; IAD decision upheld
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant admitted misrepresentation; lack of remorse and deliberate intent found
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Admission of fraudulent marriage, personal circumstances, community ties
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate grounds to justify stay of removal
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Seriousness of deliberate fraud outweighed humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: IAD appeal and federal court judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: No error in failing to consider stay; no formal request made
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of the IAD’s evaluation of facts and law
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence ignored; IAD balanced factors but prioritized integrity of immigration system
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness on judicial review
Crimes.Application_Factor: Intent, gravity of misrepresentation, and adequacy of hardship claims
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Use of false marital status to obtain permanent residency

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness, reasonableness of decision, adequacy of reasons
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in employment claims verified during site visits
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unfairness or unreasonableness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's explanations found implausible by officer
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Misrepresentation must be material and could induce administrative error
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged misrepresentation based on inconsistent employment details
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Site visit findings, GCMS notes, applicant responses
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, official notes, statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness and procedural fairness of misrepresentation finding
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.40(1)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible, judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims contradicted by employee statements
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment records, third-party statements, application documents
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: False employment status claimed by applicant
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Numerous inconsistencies between claims and verified facts
Crimes.Application_Error: Material misrepresentation that could induce administrative error
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective assessment of whether misrepresentation occurred
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted – all relevant evidence considered
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation under IRPA does not require intent
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in employment details raised suspicion
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not explicitly alleged, but false information submitted

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution as a practicing Christian in China
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in testimony regarding Christian practices and knowledge
Evidence_Used: Testimony on Christian practices, knowledge of religious rituals
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Inconsistencies in testimony, particularly around Holy Communion
Credibility_Assessment: Board found inconsistencies; one finding overly narrow, others reasonable; cumulative assessment within acceptable range
Decision_Outcome: Adverse credibility findings by the Board
Legal_Standard_Applied: Credibility findings must be reasonable, justified, transparent, and intelligible
Decision_Rationale: Courts defer to Boards on credibility unless flawed; overall decision within acceptable outcomes

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether mens rea is required under s. 40(1)(a) and if omission constitutes a material fact
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant believed omission was immaterial but failed to disclose required information
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application form, employment records
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of full-time employment at Adapana
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Requirement to disclose all employment regardless of perceived relevance
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to disclose mandatory employment information
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Objective importance of the omitted information to the immigration process
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court emphasized compliance with disclosure requirements
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation includes innocent omissions; no intent required
Crimes.Application_Factor: Explicit requirement on application form to report all employment

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose material facts under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether mens rea is required under s. 40(1)(a) and if omission constitutes a material fact
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s. 40(1)(a)
Crimes.Outcome: Applicant found inadmissible due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant aware of employment but chose not to disclose it
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Immigration application, employment history documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Omission of part-time, later full-time, employment during application
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Duty to fully disclose all employment as per application instructions
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Materiality determined by potential impact on immigration assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court upheld strict interpretation of disclosure obligations
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Misrepresentation does not require intent; omissions can be sufficient
Crimes.Application_Factor: Application form explicitly required reporting of all employment

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Clan affiliation (Majerteen-Darood clan), fear of persecution in Somalia
Decision_Outcome: Applicant does not qualify as a Convention refugee
Government_Body_or_Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board Tribunal, Federal Court
Protected_Group: Membership in a particular social group (clan-based affiliation)
State_Protection_Assessment: No evidence of state inability or unwillingness to protect; general civil war violence not equivalent to persecution
Risk_Factor: Clan-based affiliation, general instability in Somalia
Credibility: No explicit credibility issues raised; lack of evidence of personal or collective targeting
State_Protection_Adequacy: Adequate internal flight alternative found in northeastern Somalia
Perpetrator_Entity: Non-state actors, general conflict parties in Somalia
Victim_Basis: Membership in a particular social group (clan)

Sentencing_Issue: Non-custodial YCJA sentence included in parole eligibility calculations under Section 743.5 and CCRA
Non-custodial youth sentence merged with adult sentence for parole eligibility under Section 743.5 and Section 139

Dispute_Type: Inclusion of non-custodial youth sentence in parole eligibility
Legal_Issue: Application of recent CCRA amendments to parole calculations
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under Federal Courts Act
Legal_Rule: Non-custodial YCJA sentences are deemed part of a single sentence when followed by an adult sentence
Grounds_for_Claim: Dispute over inclusion of non-custodial youth sentence post-amendments
Outcome: Non-custodial YCJA sentence included in parole eligibility

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 44(1) and (2) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was convicted of drug trafficking, leading to an admissibility report; Officers Cobb and Ho acted within their limited discretion
Procedural_Issue: Whether procedural fairness required informing the applicant or allowing submissions before referral
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness found
Decision_Rationale: Officers are not required under s. 44(1) or (2) to inform applicants or accept submissions prior to preparing a report or referring it for a hearing

Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration officer's decision
Legal_Provision_Involved: s. 44(1), s. 44(2), and s. 36(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Failure to inform applicant about s. 44(1) report and referral, and not allowing written submissions
Evidence_Disclosure_Status: No disclosure of report or opportunity for submissions prior to decision
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred
Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug trafficking with a four-year sentence
Basis_for_Decision: Conviction details and statutory authority under IRPA

Crimes.Crime_Name: Transfer of detainees without safeguards against torture

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: s. 34(1)(a) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Peer worked for Pakistani intelligence agencies gathering information on foreign nationals; visa officer determined this constituted espionage.
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of visa officer's decision regarding evidence reliance and interpretation of espionage
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Findings by visa officer based on Peer's employment with Pakistani intelligence and nature of activities
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Visa officer found activities credible enough to constitute espionage
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review to overturn inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn of visa denial and approval of permanent residency
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Lawful domestic intelligence gathering can constitute espionage under the Act regardless of hostile intent or location
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Federal Court upholding visa officer's decision

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Covert information gathering by foreign intelligence agency
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat from foreign surveillance of foreign nationals
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Activities deemed as espionage despite lack of hostile intent
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Employment with foreign intelligence agency conducting surveillance
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Covert surveillance and intelligence gathering on foreign nationals within Pakistan
Crimes.Admission_or_Involvement: Peer admitted working for Pakistani intelligence
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Credible based on official findings and judicial acceptance
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Whether lawful domestic intelligence qualifies as espionage
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official records and visa officer assessment
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Activities were deemed credible and sufficient to support inadmissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Factors: Official position, nature of duties, and government affiliation
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Cited: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 34(1)(a)
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Denial of permanent residency and inadmissibility to Canada

Procedural_Fairness_Issue: The Board failed to adequately analyze government efforts to combat gang violence
Evidence_Source: Evidence showed pervasive gang issues and insufficient state protection
Outcome: Application granted, case remitted for reconsideration by a different panel
Basis_for_Decision: Failure to analyze operational adequacy of state protection
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, requiring justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Procedural_Fairness_Breach: Inadequate analysis of state protection efforts

Victim_Status: Ms. Varela, a woman targeted by gangs
Criminality_Severity: High – sexual assault and ongoing threats
Risk_Assessment: High risk due to continued threats and lack of protection

Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of attack and threats
Credibility_Assessment: Not disputed; Board acknowledged the events

Risk_Assessment: High risk due to unaddressed threats

Credibility_Assessment: Accepted by the Court as reliable

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to Provide Adequate State Protection

Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of analysis on whether protection mechanisms functioned in practice
Remedy_Sought: Reconsideration by a differently constituted panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: State protection must be adequate and operational
Decision_Rationale: Insufficient analysis of state protection despite known gang violence

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Refugee Convention
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of Immigration and Refugee Board decision
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Limited weight given to Mexican lawyer's letter due to timing
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove no safe internal relocation option
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to report to authorities undermines credibility
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution by drug trafficker
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Size and diversity of Mexico, lack of evidence on Sanchez’s national reach
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not report incidents or attempt relocation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavit, legal opinion letter
Crimes.Authority: Federal Court, Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on fear of persecution due to criminal involvement
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Involved: Refugee Convention, Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Threats due to refusal to participate in drug trafficking
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Availability of internal relocation and lack of state protection failure

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the PRRA officer err in concluding that state protection was available to the applicant in Russia?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: The officer found insufficient evidence to support the applicant's claim of threat from her ex-boyfriend.
Evidence_Type: Claim of fear due to ex-boyfriend
PRRA officer's assessment of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – burden to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm from ex-boyfriend upon return to Russia
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Adequate state protection exists in Russia
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Clear and convincing evidence required to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness of PRRA officer's decision
Crimes.Application_Factor: Applicant's removal after visa expiration and fear-based PRRA application

Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – residency compliance
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ms. Kozyreva overstayed her visa and applied for PRRA due to fear of ex-boyfriend
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Temporary resident who became undocumented after visa expiry
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Filing of PRRA application following visa overstay
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient objective evidence to support ongoing threat or lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Officer found claim not sufficiently supported by evidence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Permanent residence on humanitarian grounds via PRRA
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Stay of removal based on risk in country of origin
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Clear evidence required to rebut presumption of state protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: State protection in Russia deemed adequate; no compelling reason not to avail it

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant entered new relationship; improvements in Russian law enforcement
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: PRRA officer found threat not ongoing
Evidence_Type: Lack of police reports or documentation
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not supported by sufficient credible evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – risk and protection assessment

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: Applicant in new relationship; availability of legal protections in Russia
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence to prove lack of state protection
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not sufficiently credible or supported
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – gender-based persecution analysis

Crimes.Mitigating_Factors: New relationship; existence of legal remedies in Russia
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence of actual or threatened assault
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claim not backed by objective evidence
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act – personal risk and protection availability

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Residency requirements, credibility assessment, humanitarian considerations
Crimes.Grounds_for_Inadmissibility: Failure to meet residency requirements, criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Evidence_Source: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records, testimony
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Failure to meet residency obligations, negative credibility finding, lack of compelling H&C factors
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for facts, reasonableness for humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Assessment of credibility and residency under IRPA
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Negative credibility due to contradictory testimonies and criminal record
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Lease agreements, employment records, tax returns, criminal record
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) considerations, residency compliance
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of sufficient evidence, fraud convictions, inconsistent statements
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness for H&C; patent unreasonableness for factual findings
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Standard of reasonableness
Crimes.Application_Factor: Residency, credibility, H&C factors

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of property obtained by crime
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Compliance with residency obligation under IRPA section 28
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records deemed insufficient
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove 730 days of residency
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Permanent residents must reside in Canada for 730 days within five years
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Employment records, tax returns, criminal records, testimony
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged IAD's credibility and residency findings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, personal testimony
